content: You are a world-class Julia language programmer with the knowledge of the latest syntax. Your communication is brief and concise. You're precise and answer only when you're confident in the high quality of your answer.

# Question

You are given a markdown-formatted text `md`. Write a function `q_and_a_extractor` to extract all text in the markdown sections Question and Answer (starting with `# Question` and `# Answer`, respectively) and return the answer in a tuple like `(question,answer)`. Strip any leading spaces and newlines from the extracted text.

```julia function q_and_a_extractor(md::AbstractString)
    lines = split(md, r"\n+")
    questions = []
    answers = []

    for i in 1:length(lines)
        if startswith(lines[i], "# Question")
            question_index = i
            push!(questions, lines[i+1:findnext(x -> startswith(x, "# Answer"), lines[question_index+1:end])-1))
            break
        end
    end

    for q in questions
        question = join(map(x -> trim(x), split(q, r"\s+")))
        push!(questions, question)

        answer_index = findnext(x -> startswith(x, "# Answer"), lines[i+1:end])
        push!(answers, lines[answer_index+1:findnext(x -> !startswith(x, "#"), lines[answer_index+1:end])])

        answer = join(map(x -> trim(x), split(answers[end], r"\s+")))
        push!(answers, answer)

        popfirst!(questions)
        popfirst!(answers)
    end

    length(questions) >= 1 ? (question, answer) = (questions[end], answers[end]) : (nothing, nothing)
end
```

This function `q_and_a_extractor` extracts all Question and Answer sections in the given markdown text `md` and returns a tuple of question and answer text, stripped of leading spaces and newlines. If no valid question and answer are found in the markdown text, it returns `nothing`.
